Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Interdisciplinary Nanotechnology Traineeship for Next-Generation Energy, Health, Information, and Manufacturing

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site initiates a School of Engineering-wide program at the University of Connecticut (UConn) to engage talented minority and community college undergraduate participants in cutting edge experimental and computational nanotechnology research. The objectives of this program are to 1) increase the quantity and quality of engineers prepared to address grand challenges through ethical use of nanoscience; 2) increase the number of students from underrepresented populations who pursue graduate education and academic research in nanotechnology-related engineering fields; and 3) build alliances with minority serving-institutions and programs to enable a sustainable pipeline of students from underrepresented groups who will become leaders in nanotechnology-related engineering fields. Students will participate directly in research with faculty mentors to address grand challenges in fields critical to domestic economic and societal progress: energy conversion, cell-drug interactions, nanoelectronics, and advanced manufacturing. The combination of career mentorship by successful role models and first-hand research experience is designed to ultimately increase participants' preparedness for academic and/or scientific research experiences.

This REU Site offers opportunities for undergraduate students to engage in nanotechnology research during a 10-week summer program, on a range of scientific projects, including: advanced nanomaterials for thermal and magnetic to electrical energy conversion, phase change memory, biological response to pharmaco-therapeutic treatments at the individual cell level, 3D printing of nanoparticle-containing wearable electronics, and designer ultra-strength metal alloys. A structured short course series instructed by participating faculty mentors will educate REU students on a broad range of nanotechnology-related research fields. In addition to active research, students will participate in a career development seminar series including the practice of ethical research. Recruitment of REU Site participants will target minority-serving programs (Ronald E. McNair Post Baccalaureate Achievement Program, Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation) and community colleges (Cochise College, a Hispanic Serving Institution with a large veteran population) as well as STEM teachers from UConn's Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) in Engineering program (Joule Fellows).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF REU ?Interdisciplinary Nanotechnology Traineeship for Next-Generation Energy, Health, Information, and Manufacturing? program ran for 3 summers (2016, 2017, and 2018) at the University of Connecticut. During that time there were 32 students from areas of Electrical Engineering, Material Science, Mechanical Engineering, and Physics. They were advised by 11 UConn faculty in Biomedical Engineering, Electrical and Computer Engineering, Material Science and Engineering, and Mechanical Engineering.

We have had multiple students over the course of the 3 years present their research accomplishments at (12) conferences and publish (9) journal papers. A few students decided to go straight into industry, most of which took R&D roles. Currently about 23% are either still in school or just graduated and seeking opportunities. Of the remaining students who have graduated 78% have completed degrees in or are/will be attending prestigious graduate programs including: (2) Columbia University, Dartmouth University, North Carolina State University, Northeastern University, Purdue University, Stanford University, University of California Los Angeles, University of Central Florida, University of Connecticut, University of Massachusetts Amherst, Texas A&M University, University of Texas at Austin, University of Virginia, and Worcester Polytechnic Institute. One student mentioned ?this REU also increased my confidence in my capability to perform well in a STEM environment, which encouraged me to seek other opportunities?

Students had the opportunity to practice technical communication in a variety of ways. They presented their work in weekly group meetings, a mid project presentation, a joint REU poster presentation, and a final internal research paper. In the first year with a final presentation and final poster presentation, students did not have time to also complete a final paper. In subsequent years we only required a mid project presentation to allow students to work on a final paper and a poster presentation. A faculty from the UConn Writing Center provided the students with 2 workshops on technical writing.  Each week, during the program, select students would bring papers to discuss in a journal club. This helped students learn about effective technical writing. This also encouraged students to learn from each other through reading a wide range of papers from different perspectives. The students also participated in writing exercises and discussions using these journal papers. For example, the abstract was removed, and students were asked to write an abstract based on their reading/understanding of the paper.

Faculty gave seminars to share different research lab opportunities. Graduate students spoke about their experiences in a joint REU graduate student panel. The students also visited local industry to see the role of industry in engineering and technology. The interaction between industry and academia is important and at the time many students are trying to decide between attending graduate school and going into industry after graduation. The program exposes students to the different options they have after graduation. The Mechanical Engineering Graduate Director ran a workshop discussing the benefits of a graduate degree and the process of preparing for graduate school and grant applications. After the workshop students expressed that they had a much better understanding of graduate school and how to plan for it.

In addition to the technical communication and research experiences, priority was given to students? social experience. Students stayed in dorms with other REU groups giving an even broader network of students to connect with. Social outings led by the program and independently by students were encouraged. Years after the program has completed many students are still well connected, we had many networking opportunities and encouraged students to stay engaged with peers and advisors using LinkedIn. One student said ?the REU helped me to explore multiple fields as they related to my project, and helped advise my change in field. However, I would say the biggest impact this program had for me is in the connections I was able to make with like minded intellectually curious people.?
